text: A certain man lived in Ramathaim-zophim, which is in the hill country of Ephraim. He was Jeroham’s son Elkanah, the grandson of Elihu and grandson of Tohu, who was the son of Zuph, an Ephraimite.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had two wives; the name of one was Hannah and the name of the other was Peninnah. Peninnah had children, but Hannah had no children.
speaker: Narrator

text: That man would go up from his town each year to worship and sacrifice to the Lord of the Heavenly Armies at Shiloh, where Eli’s two sons Hophni and Phineas served as priests of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day when Elkanah offered sacrifices, he would give portions to his wife Peninnah and to all her sons and daughters,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but he would give twice as much to Hannah because he loved her.
Now the Lord had closed her womb.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her rival would provoke her severely so that she complained loudly because the Lord had closed her womb.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elkanah would do this year after year, as often as Hannah went up to the house of the Lord. Likewise, Peninnah would provoke her, and Hannah would cry and would not eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elkanah her husband told her, “Hannah, why are you crying and why don’t you eat? Why are you upset? Am I not better to you than ten sons?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hannah got up after she had finished eating and drinking in Shiloh. Now Eli the priest was sitting on the chair by the doorpost of the tent of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Deeply distressed, she prayed to the Lord and wept bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hannah made a vow: “Lord of the Heavenly Armies, if you just look at the misery of your maid servant, remember me, and don’t forget your maid servant. If you give your maid servant a son, then I’ll give him to the Lord for all the days of his life, and a razor is never to touch his head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As she continued to pray in the Lord’s presence, Eli was watching her mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hannah was praying inwardly. Her lips were quivering, and her voice could not be heard. So Eli thought she was drunk.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eli told her, “How long will you stay drunk? Put away your wine!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No, sir!” Hannah replied. “I’m a deeply troubled woman. I’ve drunk neither wine nor beer. I’ve been pouring out my soul in the Lord’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t consider your maid servant a worthless woman. Rather, all this time I’ve been speaking because I’m very anxious and distressed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go in peace,” Eli answered. “May the God of Israel grant the request you have asked of him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “Let your servant find favor in your eyes.” Then she went on her way and ate, and her face was no longer sad.
speaker: Narrator

text: They got up early the next morning and worshipped in the Lord’s presence, and then they returned and came to their house at Ramah. Elkanah had marital relations with his wife Hannah, and the Lord remembered her.
speaker: Narrator

text: By the time of the next year’s sacrifice, Hannah had become pregnant and had borne a son. She named him Samuel because she said, “I asked the Lord for him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elkanah went up with all his family to offer the yearly sacrifice to the Lord and pay his vow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hannah did not go up because she had told her husband, “As soon as the child is weaned, I’ll take him to appear in the Lord’s presence and remain there forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do what you want,” Elkanah told her. “Stay until you have weaned him, only may the Lord bring about what you’ve said.” So Hannah stayed and nursed her son until she had weaned him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, when she had weaned him, she brought him up with her to Shiloh, along with a three-year-old bull, an ephah of flour, and a skin of wine. She brought him to the house of the Lord at Shiloh, and the boy was young.
speaker: Narrator

text: They slaughtered the bull and brought the boy to Eli.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hannah said, “Sir, as surely as you are alive, I’m the woman who stood before you here praying to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I prayed for this boy, and the Lord granted me the request I asked of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I’m dedicating him to the Lord, and as long as he lives, he will be dedicated to the Lord.” Then they worshipped the Lord there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Hannah prayed:
“My heart exults in the Lord;
    my strength is increased by the Lord.
I will open my mouth to speak against my enemies,
    because I rejoice in your deliverance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, there is no one holy like the Lord,
    indeed, there is no one besides you,
there is no rock like our God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t continue to talk proudly,
    and don’t speak arrogantly,
for the Lord is a God of knowledge,
    and by him actions are weighed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The bows of warriors are shattered,
    but those who stumble are equipped with strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who had an abundance of bread
    now hire themselves out,
and those who were hungry
    hunger no more.
While the barren woman gives birth to seven children,
    she who had many children languishes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord kills and gives life,
    he brings people down to where the dead are
        and he raises them up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord makes people poor
    and he makes people rich,
he brings them low,
    and he also exalts them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He raises the poor up from the dust,
    he lifts up the needy from the trash heap
to make them sit with princes
    and inherit a seat of honor.
Indeed the pillars of the earth belong to the Lord,
    and he has set the world on them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He guards the steps of his faithful ones,
    while the wicked are made silent in darkness.
He grants the request of the one who prays.
    He blesses the year of the righteous.
Indeed it’s not by strength that a person prevails.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord will shatter his enemies
    —those who contend against him.
Who is holy?
    The one who will thunder against them in the heavens.
The Lord will judge the ends of the earth,
    he will give strength to his king,
        and he will increase the strength of His anointed one.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elkanah went to his house at Ramah, while the boy was ministering to the Lord in the presence of Eli the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the sons of Eli were worthless men who did not know the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The custom of the priests with the people was that whenever a person offered a sacrifice, a servant of the priest would come with a three pronged fork in his hand while the meat was boiling, and
speaker: Narrator

text: he would stick it into the boiler or pot, and take everything the fork brought up—that is, the priest would take it for himself. This is what they were supposed to do with all the Israelis who came there to Shiloh.
speaker: Narrator

text: But even before they burned the fat, the servant of the priest would come and say to the person offering the sacrifice, “Give me meat to roast for the priest. He won’t accept boiled meat from you, but only raw.”
speaker: Narrator

text: If the man told him, “They must surely burn up the fat first, and then take for yourself whatever you desire,” the servant would say, “No, give it now, and if you don’t, I’ll take it by force!”
speaker: Narrator

text: By doing this, the sin of the young men was very serious in the Lord’s sight because the men despised the Lord’s offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Samuel was ministering in the Lord’s presence, as a boy wearing a linen ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: His mother would make a small robe for him, and she would bring it each year when she went up with her husband to offer the yearly sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eli would bless Elkanah and his wife and say, “May the Lord give you descendants from this woman in place of the one she dedicated to the Lord.” Then they would return to their home.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord took note of Hannah, and she became pregnant and gave birth to three sons and two daughters. Meanwhile, the boy Samuel continued to grow, and the Lord was constantly with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Eli was very old, and he had heard everything that his sons were doing to the Israelis, and how they lay with the women who were serving regularly at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why are you doing these things that I’m hearing about?” he asked his sons, “These reports about your evil deeds are coming from all these people!
speaker: Narrator

text: No, my sons, I’m not hearing good news being circulated by the Lord’s people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a person sins against another, God will mediate for him, but if a person sins against the Lord, who can intercede for him?”
But they would not follow the advice of their father; for the Lord wanted to put them to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the boy Samuel continued to grow both physically and in favor with the Lord and the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man of God came to Eli, saying to him, “This is what the Lord says: ‘When they were in Egypt and slaves to the house of Pharaoh, did I not reveal to the family of your ancestor Aaron
speaker: Narrator

text: that I had chosen him out of all the tribes of Israel to be my priest, to offer up burnt offerings on my altar, burn incense, and carry the ephod in my presence? And did I not give to your ancestors’ family all the Israeli fire-offerings?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why, then, do all of you show contempt for my sacrifice and offering that I’ve commanded for my dwelling? And you honor your sons more than me in order to fatten yourselves from the best of all the offerings of my people Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, the Lord God of Israel has declared, ‘I did, in fact, say that your family and your ancestor’s family would walk before me forever,’ but now the Lord declares, ‘Far be it from me! The one who honors me I’ll honor, and the one who despises me is to be treated with contempt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The time is coming when I’ll cut away at your family and your ancestor’s family until there are no old men left in your family.
speaker: Narrator

text: Distress will settle down to live in your household, and despite all the good that I do for Israel, there will never be an old man in your family forever, and you will never again have an old man in my house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any of you whom I don’t eliminate from serving at my altar will grow tired from weeping, and their souls will grieve. All the increase of your family will die by violence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here’s a sign for you—your two sons Hophni and Phineas will both die on the same day!
speaker: Narrator

text: And I’ll raise up for myself a faithful priest who will do according to what is in my heart and according to my desire. I’ll build for him an enduring house and he will walk before my anointed one forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who remains in your family will come and prostrate themselves before him for a small wage or a loaf of bread and will say, “Please put me in one of the priest’s offices so I can eat a piece of bread.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile the boy Samuel was serving the Lord before Eli. A word from the Lord was rare in those days, and visions were infrequent.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Eli, whose vision was growing dim, was lying down in his bedroom.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lamp of God had not yet been extinguished, and Samuel was lying down in the tent of the Lord where the Ark of God was.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord called out to Samuel, who answered, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He ran to Eli and said, “Here I am! You called me.”
“I didn’t call you,” Eli said. “Go back and lie down.” So he went and lay down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord again called out, “Samuel!”
So Samuel got up, went to Eli, and said, “Here I am! You called me.”
He said, “I didn’t call you, my son. Go back and lie down.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Samuel did not yet know the Lord and had not yet had the word of the Lord revealed to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord called out to Samuel again a third time, and he got up, went to Eli, and said, “Here I am! You called me.”
Then Eli understood that the Lord was calling the boy,
speaker: Narrator

text: so Eli told Samuel, “Go lie down, and then if he calls you, answer, ‘Speak, Lord, because your servant is listening.’” Then Samuel went and lay down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Later, the Lord came and stood there, calling out, “Samuel! Samuel!” as he had before.
Samuel said, “Speak, because your servant is listening.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look,” the Lord told Samuel. “I’m about to do something in Israel that will make both ears of anyone who hears it tingle.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll fulfill every promise that I’ve spoken concerning Eli’s family, from beginning to end.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ve told him that I’m about to judge his family forever because of the iniquity that he knew about. His sons committed blasphemy and he did not rebuke them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I’ve sworn concerning Eli’s family that the iniquity of his family is not to be atoned for by sacrifice or offering forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel lay down until morning and then opened the doors of the house of the Lord, but he was afraid to report the vision to Eli.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Eli called Samuel: “Samuel, my son.”
He said, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Eli said, “What did the Lord say to you? Please don’t conceal anything from me. May God do this to you and even more if you conceal from me one word of all that he spoke to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel told him everything—he did not conceal anything from him. Eli said, “He is the Lord. May he do what seems good to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Samuel grew, the Lord was with him and did not let any of Samuel’s predictions fail.
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel from Dan to Beer-sheba knew that Samuel was confirmed as the Lord’s prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued to appear at Shiloh, because he revealed himself to Samuel at Shiloh by means of messages from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: What Samuel had to say was directed to all Israel, and Israel went out to engage the Philistines in battle. The Israelis were camped at Ebenezer, while the Philistines were camped at Aphek.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines deployed their forces to meet Israel, and as the battle spread Israel was defeated by the Philistines, who killed about four thousand men on the battlefield.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people came to the camp, the elders of Israel said, “Why did the Lord defeat us today when we fought the Philistines? Let’s take the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord from Shiloh, so it may go with us and deliver us from the power of our enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the people sent word to Shiloh and took away from there the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, who sits above the cherubim.
Now the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phineas, were there with the Ark of the Covenant of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord came into the camp, all Israel gave a great shout and the earth reverberated!
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistines heard the noise of the shout, they asked, “What is this noise coming from shouting in the camp of the Hebrews?” Then they realized that the Ark of the Lord had come into the camp,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Philistines were terrified. “God has come into the camp,” they said. “How terrible for us, because nothing like this has ever happened before!
speaker: Narrator

text: How terrible for us! Who will deliver us from the hand of these mighty gods? These are the gods who struck the Egyptians with all kinds of plagues in the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: Philistines, be strong and be men, or you will become slaves to the Hebrews just as they have been slaves to you! Be men and fight!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines fought and Israel was defeated; each of them fled to his own tent. It was a very great slaughter, and 30,000 soldiers of Israel died.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ark of God was captured, and the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phineas, died.
speaker: Narrator

text: That very same day, a man who was a descendant of Benjamin ran from the battle line and came to Shiloh, with his garments torn and dirt on his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he arrived, Eli was sitting there on a seat beside the road, watching because his heart trembled for the Ark of God. The man went into the town to give the report, and the whole town cried out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eli heard the sound of the cry and asked, “What is the meaning of this commotion?” Then the man quickly came and told Eli.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Eli was 98 years old, and his vision had failed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The man told Eli, “I’ve just come from the battle line, and I escaped from the battle today.”
He asked, “What happened, my son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The messenger answered, “Israel fled from the Philistines and the people suffered a great defeat as well. Moreover, your two sons, Hophni and Phineas, are dead, and the Ark of God was captured.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he mentioned the Ark of God, Eli fell off the seat backwards by the side of the gate. His neck was broken and he died, since he was old and heavy. Eli had judged Israel for 40 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eli’s daughter-in-law, the wife of Phineas, was pregnant and ready to give birth. When she heard the report about the capture of the Ark of God and that her father-in-law and husband were dead, she crouched down and gave birth, because her labor pains suddenly began.
speaker: Narrator

text: As she was about to die, the women standing around her said, “Don’t be afraid! You’ve given birth to a son.” But she did not respond or pay attention.
speaker: Narrator

text: She had named the boy Ichabod, saying, “Glory has departed from Israel,” because the Ark of God had been captured and because her father-in-law and husband were dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “Glory has departed from Israel, because the Ark of God has been captured.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines took the Ark of God and brought it from Ebenezer to Ashdod.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Philistines took the Ark of God, brought it to the temple of Dagon, and placed it beside Dagon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people of Ashdod got up the next morning, there was Dagon, lying on the ground in front of the Ark of the Lord. They took Dagon and put him back in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they got up the next morning, there was Dagon, lying on the ground again in front of the Ark of the Lord. Dagon’s head and both of his arms were broken off and lying on the threshold. Only the trunk of Dagon was left intact.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is why neither the priests of Dagon nor anyone who enters the temple of Dagon step on the threshold of Dagon in Ashdod to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord heavily oppressed the people of Ashdod, devastating and afflicting Ashdod and its territories with tumors of the groin.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of Ashdod saw how things were, they said, “Don’t let the Ark of the God of Israel stay with us, because he is severely attacking us and our god Dagon.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They sent messengers and gathered together all the lords of the Philistines and asked, “What are we to do with the Ark of the God of Israel?”
They said, “Let the Ark of the God of Israel move to Gath.” So they moved the Ark of the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they moved it, the Lord moved against the town, causing a very great panic. He struck the men of the town, from young to old with tumors of the groin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they sent the Ark of God to Ekron. When the Ark of God arrived in Ekron, the people of Ekron cried out, “They have brought the Ark of the God of Israel to us to kill us and our people!”
speaker: Narrator

text: They sent messengers and gathered together all the Philistine lords: “Send away the Ark of the God of Israel, and let it return to where it belongs so that it does not kill us and our people.” Meanwhile, a deadly panic had spread all over the town, and God kept on pressuring them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people who did not die were afflicted with tumors of the groin, and the cry of the town went up to heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ark of the Lord remained in Philistine territory for seven months.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines summoned the priests and diviners and asked, “What should we do about the Ark of the Lord? Tell us how we should send it back to its place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “If you send the Ark of the God of Israel back, don’t send it empty, but rather be sure to send back to him a guilt offering. Then you will be healed and will know why his oppression has not been removed from you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They asked, “What is the guilt offering that we should send back to him?”
“Five gold tumors and five gold mice,” they answered, “according to the number of the lords of the Philistines, since the same plague was on all of you and on your lords.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make images of your tumors and images of the mice that are destroying your land, and you are to give glory to the God of Israel. Perhaps he will remove his pressure from you, your gods, and your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why should you harden your hearts just as the Egyptians and Pharaoh hardened their hearts? Isn’t it true that after God toyed with them, they let Israel go, and off they went?
speaker: Narrator

text: “So make a new cart, and take two milk cows that have never had a yoke on them. Hitch the cows to the cart and take their calves away from them and back to the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take the Ark of the Lord, put it on the cart, and put the gold objects that you are returning to him as a guilt offering in a box beside it. Then send it away and let it go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep watching it. If it goes up along the road to its own territory to Beth-shemesh, it’s the Lord who has done this great evil to us. But if it does not, then we will know that he wasn’t pressuring us. It happened to us as a natural event.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men did this. They took two milk cows, hitched them to the cart, and penned up their calves in the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: They put the Ark of the Lord, the box, the gold mice, and the images of their tumors on the cart.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cows took a straight path along the road to Beth-shemesh. They stayed on the highway, lowing as they went, and did not turn to the right or the left. The Philistine lords followed them as far as the border of Beth-shemesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the people of Beth-shemesh were gathering their wheat harvest in the valley. They looked up, saw the Ark, and rejoiced to see it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cart came to the field of Joshua of Beth-shemesh, and stopped there. In that place there was a large stone. They broke up the wood from the cart, and offered up the cows as a burnt offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Levi took down the Ark of the Lord, along with the box that was with it, containing the objects of gold, and they put them on the large stone. The men of Beth-shemesh offered burnt offerings and made sacrifices to the Lord that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the five Philistine lords saw this, they returned to Ekron that very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the gold tumors that the Philistines returned as a guilt offering to the Lord: one for Ashdod, one for Gaza, one for Ashkelon, one for Gath, and one for Ekron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gold mice represented the number of all the Philistine towns belonging to the five lords, both fortified towns and unwalled villages. The large stone, beside which they put the Ark of the Lord, is a witness to this day in the field of Joshua of Beth-shemesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: God struck down the men of Beth-shemesh because they had looked into the Ark of the Lord. He struck down 50,070 men among the people, and the people mourned because the Lord struck down the people with a great slaughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Beth-shemesh asked themselves, “Who can stand in the presence of the Lord, this holy God? And to whom will the Ark go from here?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They sent messengers to the residents of Kiriath-jearim, who told them, “The Philistines have returned the Ark of the Lord. Come down and take it up with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Kiriath-jearim came and took the Ark of the Lord. They brought it to the house of Abinadab on the hill, and they consecrated his son Eleazar to care for the Ark of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: A long time passed—it was twenty years—from the time the Ark came to reside in Kiriath-jearim, and all the house of Israel mourned because of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel told the whole house of Israel, “If you’re returning to the Lord with all your heart, then remove the foreign gods and the Ashtaroth from among you, direct your hearts back to the Lord, and serve him only. Then he will deliver you from the control of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelis removed the Baals and Ashtaroth, and served the Lord only.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Bring all Israel together at Mizpah, and I’ll pray to the Lord on your behalf.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they came together at Mizpah, drew water, and poured it out in the Lord’s presence.
On that day they fasted there and said, “We have sinned against the Lord.” Then Samuel judged the Israelis at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistines heard that the Israelis had gathered at Mizpah, the Philistine lords came up against Israel. When the Israelis heard this, they were afraid of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelis told Samuel, “Don’t stop crying out to the Lord our God for us that he may deliver us from the hand of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel took a nursing lamb and offered it as a whole burnt offering to the Lord. Samuel cried out to the Lord on behalf of Israel, and the Lord answered him.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Samuel was sacrificing the burnt offering, the Philistines approached to attack Israel. But that day the Lord thundered against the Philistines and threw them into panic, and they were defeated before Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel went out from Mizpah, pursued the Philistines, and struck them down as far as a point below Beth-car.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel took a stone, placed it between Mizpah and Shen and named it Ebenezer. He said, “The Lord has helped us this far.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Philistines were subdued, and they did not continue to enter the territory of Israel.
The Lord continued to oppose the Philistines all during Samuel’s life time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The towns that the Philistines had taken from Israel were returned to Israel, from Ekron to Gath, and Israel delivered their territory from Philistine control. There was also peace between Israel and the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel judged Israel all the days of his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went on a circuit each year to Bethel, Gilgal, and Mizpah, and he judged Israel in all those places.
speaker: Narrator

text: He would return to Ramah because his house was there, and judged Israel from there. He also built an altar to the Lord there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Samuel became old, he appointed his sons judges over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of his firstborn son was Joel and the name of his second was Abijah. They were judges in Beer-sheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sons did not follow Samuel’s example. Instead, they pursued dishonest gain, took bribes, and perverted justice.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the elders of Israel gathered together, and came to Samuel at Ramah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They told him, “Look, you’re old, and your sons don’t follow your example. So appoint a king to govern us like all the other nations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel was displeased when they said, “Give us a king to govern us.” So Samuel prayed to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Samuel, “Listen to the people in all that they say to you. In fact, it’s not you they have rejected, but rather they have rejected me from being their king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Like all the things they have done from the day I brought them up out of Egypt until this very day, they have forsaken me and followed other gods. They’re also doing the same thing to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, listen to them, but you are to clearly warn them and inform them about how the king who rules over them will operate.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel reported everything the Lord told him to the people who were asking him for a king.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “This is how the king who rules over you will operate: He will conscript your sons and assign them to his chariots. He will conscript them as his horsemen, and they’ll run in front of his chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will appoint his officers over thousands and officers over fifties—some will plow his fields, reap his harvest, and craft his war implements and equipment for his chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take your daughters for perfumers, cooks, and bakers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take the best products of your fields, your vineyards, and your olive groves and give them to his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take a tenth of your seed and your vineyards and give it to his officers and servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take your male and female servants, your best young men, and your donkeys to do his work.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take a tenth of your flock, and you will become his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all of this comes about, you will cry out because of your king whom you chose for yourselves, but the Lord won’t answer you at that time.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people refused to listen to Samuel. Instead, they insisted, “No! Let a king rule over us instead!
speaker: Narrator

text: We, too, will be like all the nations! Our king will govern us and go out before us to fight our battles.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel listened to all the words of the people, and he repeated them directly to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord told Samuel, “Listen to them, and appoint a king for them.”
Then Samuel told the men of Israel, “Each of you go to his own town.”
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a man from Benjamin named Kish, Abiel’s son, the grandson of Zeror and great-grandson of Aphiah’s son Becorath. A prominent man from Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: he had a son named Saul, who was a choice and handsome young man. There was no one among the Israelis as handsome as he, and he was a head taller than any of the other people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The donkeys belonging to Kish, Saul’s father, were lost, and Kish told his son Saul, “Take one of the young men with you, get up, and go look for the donkeys.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He went through the hill country of Ephraim and through the region of Shalishah, but they did not find them. Then they went through the region of Shaalim, but they were not there. They also went through the territory of the descendants of Benjamin, but they did not find them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they entered the region of Zuph, Saul told the young man with him, “Come on, let’s go back so my father does not stop worrying about the donkeys and become anxious about us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The young man said, “Look, there’s a man of God in this town. The man is respected, and everything he predicts happens. Now, let’s go there. Perhaps he can tell us about the journey on which we have set out.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told the young man, “Look, we could go, but what could we bring the man? The bread is gone from our bags, and there is no present to bring to the man of God. What do we have with us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The young man answered Saul again, “Look here! I have in my hand a quarter shekel of silver. I’ll give it to the man of God, and he will tell us about our journey.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (Previously in Israel, a person would say when he went to inquire of God, “Come on! Let’s go to the seer!” because the person known as a prophet today was formerly called a seer.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told his young man, “That’s a good suggestion! Come on, let’s go!” Then they entered the town where the man of God was.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were going up the hill to the town, they met some young women going out to draw water, and they told them, “Is the seer here?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They answered them: “Yes, he’s right there ahead of you. Hurry, for he came to town just today because there is a sacrifice for the people on the high place today.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you come into town you can find him before he goes up to the high place to eat. For the people don’t eat until he arrives, because he must bless the sacrifice and then after that those who are invited will eat. So go up right now because you can find him now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They went up to the town, and as they were coming to the center of the town, Samuel was coming out to meet them, on his way up to the high place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now one day before Saul’s arrival, the Lord had revealed to Samuel:
speaker: Narrator

text: “About this time tomorrow I’ll send you a man from the land of Benjamin, and you are to anoint him as Commander-in-Chief over my people Israel. He’ll deliver my people from the control of the Philistines, because I’ve seen the suffering of my people and because their cry has come up to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Samuel saw Saul, the Lord told him, “Here is the man I told you about. This man will rule over my people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Saul approached Samuel in the middle of the gate, he said, “Please tell me where the seer’s house is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel answered Saul: “I’m the seer. Go up ahead of me to the high place, and eat with me today. In the morning I’ll send you away and tell you everything that is on your mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as for your donkeys that were lost three days ago, don’t give any thought to them, because they’ve been found. Meanwhile, to whom is all Israel looking, if not to you and all of your father’s household?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul answered: “Am I not a descendant of Benjamin from the least of the tribes of Israel? Isn’t my family the least important of all the families of the tribe of Benjamin? Why have you spoken to me like this?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel took Saul and his young man and brought them to a room where he gave them a place at the head of those who were invited, of whom there were about 30 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel told the cook, “Bring the portion that I gave you, the one I told you to set aside.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The cook picked up the thigh and what was on it and set it in front of Saul. Then Samuel said, “Here is what is left! Set it before you and eat, for it has been kept for you until the appointed time, about which I said, ‘I’ve invited the people.’” So Saul ate with Samuel that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had come down from the high place into town, Samuel spoke to Saul on the roof.
speaker: Narrator

text: They got up early in the morning, and about daybreak Samuel called to Saul on the roof, “Get up and I’ll send you off.” Saul got up and the two of them, he and Samuel, went outside.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were going down to the edge of the town, Samuel told Saul, “Tell your young man to go ahead of us and when he has gone ahead, stop for a while so I may declare God’s word to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel took a flask of oil, poured it on Saul’s head, kissed him, and said, “The Lord has anointed you Commander-in-Chief over his inheritance, has he not?
speaker: Narrator

text: When you leave me today, you will find two men by Rachel’s tomb in the territory of Benjamin at Zelzah. They’ll tell you, ‘The donkeys you went to look for have been found. Now your father has stopped worrying about the donkeys and he’s anxious about you. He’s asking, ‘What will I do about my son?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you’ll go on further from there and come to the oak at Tabor. There three men going up to the Lord at Bethel will meet you. One will be herding three young goats, one will be carrying three loaves of bread, and one will be carrying a bottle of wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: They’ll greet you and give you two loaves of bread, which you’re to accept from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “After that you will come to Gibeath-elohim where the Philistine garrison is. As you arrive there at the town, you’ll meet a band of prophets coming down from the high place with a harp, tambourine, flute, and lyre being played in front of them, and they’ll be prophesying.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit of the Lord will come upon you, and you’ll prophesy with them and be changed into a different person.
speaker: Narrator

text: When these signs occur, do whatever you want to do, because the Lord is with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to go down ahead of me to Gilgal, and then I’ll come down to offer burnt offerings and to sacrifice peace offerings. You are to wait seven days until I come to you to let you know what you are to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it happened as Saul turned his back to leave Samuel, that God gave him another heart, and all these signs occurred on that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arrived there at Gibeah, a band of prophets was right there to meet them. The Spirit of God came upon Saul, and he prophesied along with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all those who had known Saul previously saw that he was there among the prophets prophesying, the people told one another, “What has happened to Kish’s son? Is Saul also among the prophets?”
speaker: Narrator

text: A man from there answered: “Now who is their father?” Therefore it became a proverb, “Is Saul also among the prophets?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had finished prophesying, he went to the high place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul’s uncle told him and to his young man, “Where did you go?”
He said, “To look for the donkeys, and when we saw that they couldn’t be found, we went to Samuel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul’s uncle said, “Please tell me what Samuel told you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told his uncle, “He actually told us that the donkeys had been found,” but he did not tell him about the matter of kingship about which Samuel had spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel summoned the people to the Lord at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told the Israelis, “This is what the Lord God of Israel says: ‘I brought Israel up out of Egypt, and I rescued you from the power of Egypt and from the power of all the kingdoms that were oppressing you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But today you have rejected your God who delivers you from all your troubles and difficulties. You have said, ‘No! Instead, appoint a king over us.’ Now present yourselves in the Lord’s presence by your tribes and families.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel brought forward all the tribes of Israel, and the tribe of Benjamin was chosen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought forward the tribe of Benjamin according to its families, and the family of Matri was chosen. Finally, Kish’s son Saul was chosen, but when they looked for him, they couldn’t find him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they inquired further of the Lord, “Has the man come here yet?”
The Lord said, “He is here, hiding among the baggage.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They ran and brought him from there. When he stood among the people, he was taller than any of the others by a head.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Samuel told all the people, “Do you see the man whom the Lord has chosen? For there is no one like him among all the people.”
Then all the people shouted, “Long live the king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel explained to the people the regulations concerning kingship. He wrote them in a scroll and placed it in the Lord’s presence. Then Samuel sent all the people to their own houses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul also went to his house in Gibeah, and the soldiers whose hearts God had touched went with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But some troublemakers said, “How can this man deliver us?” They despised him and did not bring him a gift. But Saul remained silent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Nahash, king of the Ammonites, had been severely oppressing the descendants of Gad and descendants of Reuben, gouging out their right eyes and not allowing Israel to have a deliverer. No one was left among the Israelis across the Jordan whose right eye Nahash, king of the Ammonites, had not gouged out. However, 7,000 men had escaped from the Ammonites and entered Jabesh-gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: So after a month, Nahash the Ammonite came up and laid siege to Jabesh-gilead. All the men of Jabesh told Nahash, “Make a covenant with us, and we will serve you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nahash the Ammonite told them, “I’ll make a covenant with you on the condition that I gouge out the right eye of every one of you and so bring disgrace on all Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of Jabesh told him, “Leave us alone for seven days so that we may send messengers through all the territory of Israel. Then if no one delivers us, we will come out to you and surrender.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the messengers came to Gibeah of Saul and reported the terms to the people, all the people cried loudly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then Saul was coming in from the field behind the oxen and he said, “What’s with the people? Why are they crying?” They reported to him what the men of Jabesh had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul heard these words, the Spirit of God came on him, and he was very angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took a yoke of oxen, cut them in pieces, and sent the pieces by messengers through all the territory of Israel: “This is what will be done to the oxen of anyone who does not come out and join Saul and Samuel!” The fear of the Lord fell on the people and they came out as one man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul mustered them at Bezek, and there were 300,000 Israelis and 30,000 men of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They told the messengers who had come, “You are to say this to the men of Jabesh-gilead, ‘Tomorrow, by the time the sun is hot, you will be delivered.’” The messengers went and reported to the men of Jabesh, and they rejoiced.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Jabesh said, “Tomorrow we will come out to you and surrender. Then you can do whatever you want to us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day Saul separated the people into three companies. They came into the camp during the morning watch, and struck down the Ammonites until the heat of the day. Those who survived were scattered so that no two of them remained together.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people told Samuel, “Who said, ‘Will Saul reign over us?’ Bring them to us and we will put them to death!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Saul said, “Let no one be put to death this day, because today the Lord has delivered Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel told the people, “Come, let’s go to Gilgal and reaffirm the kingship there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the people went to Gilgal and there they made Saul king in the Lord’s presence in Gilgal. There they sacrificed peace offerings in the Lord’s presence, and there Saul and all the men of Israel rejoiced greatly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel told all Israel, “Take note! I’ve listened to you, to everything you have told me, and I’ve appointed a king over you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now here is the king walking before you, while I’m old and gray, and my sons are with you. I’ve walked before you from my youth until this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here I am. Testify against me in the Lord’s presence and before his anointed. Whose ox have I taken, or whose donkey have I taken? Who have I cheated? Who have I oppressed? Who bribed me to look the other way? I’ll restore it to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “You haven’t cheated us or oppressed us, and you haven’t taken anything from anyone’s hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He told them, “Today the Lord is testifying, along with his anointed, that you haven’t found any bribes in my possession.”
They said, “He’s a witness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel told the people, “It is the Lord who appointed Moses and Aaron and who brought your ancestors up out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now stand up and I’ll pass judgment on you in light of the Lord’s righteous acts that he did for you and your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Jacob went to Egypt, and your ancestors cried out to the Lord, he sent Moses and Aaron, who brought your ancestors out of Egypt and settled them in this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they forgot the Lord their God, so he handed them over to the domination of Sisera, the commander of the army of Hazor, and into domination by the Philistines and by the king of Moab, and Israel fought against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then they cried out to the Lord: ‘We have sinned because we have forsaken the Lord and have served the Baals and the Ashtaroth. Now deliver us from the hand of our enemies, and we will serve you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord sent Jerubbaal, Barak, Jephthah, and Samuel and he delivered you from the hand of your enemies on every side, so that you lived securely.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when you saw that Nahash, king of the Ammonites, was coming to fight you, you told me, ‘No, let a king rule over us instead,’ even though the Lord your God was your king.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, here is the king you have chosen, the one whom you asked for. See, the Lord has appointed a king over you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you fear the Lord, serve him, obey him, and don’t rebel against the commandment of the Lord, then both you and the king who rules over you will truly follow the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you don’t obey the Lord and rebel against the commandment of the Lord, then the Lord will turn against you as he did against your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now then, stand up and see this great thing that the Lord is about to do before your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it not the wheat harvest today? I’ll call upon the Lord, and he will send thunder and rain. Then you will know and understand that you have done a great evil in the sight of the Lord by asking for a king for yourselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel called upon the Lord that same day, and the Lord sent thunder and rain. So all the people greatly feared the Lord and Samuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people told Samuel, “Pray to the Lord your God for your servants, so that we don’t die, because we made all our sins worse by asking for a king for ourselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel told all the people, “Don’t be afraid. You have done all this evil. Yet don’t turn aside from following the Lord, but serve the Lord with all your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t turn aside after useless things that cannot profit or deliver because they’re useless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, the Lord won’t abandon His people for the sake of His great name, for the Lord desires to make you a people for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as for me, far be it from me that I should sin against the Lord by ceasing to pray for you. I’ll also instruct you in the way that is good and right.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only, fear the Lord and serve him faithfully with all your heart. Indeed, consider what great things he has done for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you persist in doing evil, both you and your king will be swept away.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul was 30 years old when he began to reign, and he ruled for 42 years over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul chose for himself 3,000 men from Israel. There were 2,000 with Saul in Michmash and the hill country of Bethel, while 1,000 were with Jonathan in Gibeah of Benjamin. He had sent the rest of the people home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan attacked the Philistine garrison in Geba, and the Philistines heard about it. Saul blew the trumpet throughout the land: “Listen, Hebrews!”
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel heard the report, “Saul has attacked the Philistine garrison and Israel has also become repulsive to the Philistines.” Then the people were summoned to Saul at Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines assembled to fight against Israel with 30,000 chariots, 6,000 horsemen, and people as numerous as the sand on the seashore. And they advanced and camped in Michmash, east of Beth-aven.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of Israel saw that they were in distress (for the people were in difficult circumstances), the people hid themselves in caves, in thickets, in crags, in tombs, and in pits.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hebrews went across the Jordan to the land of Gad and Gilead, but Saul remained in Gilgal, and all the people followed him, trembling.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul waited seven days for the appointment set by Samuel. When Samuel did not arrive at Gilgal, as the people began to scatter from Saul,
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “Bring the burnt offering and the peace offering to me,” and he offered the burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as he finished offering the burnt offering, Samuel arrived, and Saul went out to meet and greet him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel said, “What have you done?”
Saul replied, “When? I saw that the people were scattering from me, that you didn’t come at the appointed time, and that the Philistines were assembling at Michmash.
speaker: Narrator

text: I thought, ‘The Philistines will come down against me at Gilgal but I’ve not sought the favor of the Lord,’ so I forced myself to offer the burnt offering.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel told Saul, “You have acted foolishly. You haven’t obeyed the commandment of the Lord your God, which he commanded you. For then the Lord would have established your kingdom over Israel forever,
speaker: Narrator

text: but now your kingdom won’t be established. The Lord has sought for himself a man after his own heart, and the Lord has appointed him as Commander-in-Chief over his people because you didn’t obey that which the Lord commanded you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel got up and went from Gilgal to Gibeah of Benjamin. Saul mustered the people present with him, about 600 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul, his son Jonathan, and the people present with them remained in Geba of Benjamin, while the Philistines camped in Michmash.
speaker: Narrator

text: Raiders went out of the Philistine camp in three companies. One company turned in the direction of Ophrah, to the land of Shual,
speaker: Narrator

text: one company turned in the direction of Beth-horon, while the one company turned toward the border that overlooks the valley of Zeboiim toward the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: No blacksmith could be found in all the land of Israel because the Philistines thought, “This will keep the Hebrews from making swords or spears.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone in Israel would have to go to the Philistines so each person could sharpen his plow, his mattock, his axe, and his sickle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The charge was one pin for plows, mattocks, three pronged forks, and axes, or for setting the goads.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day of battle, none of the people who were with Saul and Jonathan were armed with swords or spears, but Saul and his son Jonathan did have them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a garrison of the Philistines had gone out to the pass of Michmash.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Jonathan told his armor bearer, “Come, let’s go over to the Philistine garrison which is on the other side,” but he did not tell his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul was sitting on the outskirts of Geba under the pomegranate tree which was at Migron, and with him were about 600 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with him were Ahitub’s son Ahijah, Ichabod’s brother, who was Phineas’ son and a grandson of Eli the priest of the Lord at Shiloh, who was carrying the ephod. The people did not know that Jonathan had gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now in the pass through which Jonathan planned to get across to the Philistine garrison, there was a sharp crag on one side and a sharp crag on the other side. The name of the one was Bozez, and the name of the other was Seneh.
speaker: Narrator

text: One crag rose on the north opposite Michmash, and the other on the south opposite Geba.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan told his armor bearer, “Come, let’s go over to the garrison of these uncircumcised ones. Perhaps the Lord will work for us, since nothing prevents the Lord from delivering, whether by many or by a few.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His armor bearer told him, “Do whatever you want. Let’s move out! I’m right here with you, as you wish.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said, “Look, we’re going over to the men, and we will show ourselves to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they say to us, ‘Stay there until we come to you,’ then we will stay where we are and not go up to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they say, ‘Come up and fight us,’ then we will go up, for the Lord has given them into our hands, and this will be the sign for us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the two of them showed themselves to the Philistine garrison, the Philistines said, “Look, the Hebrews are coming out of the holes where they have been hiding.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The men of the garrison responded to Jonathan and his armor bearer: “Come up and fight us, and we will show you something.”
Jonathan then told his armor bearer, “Follow me, for the Lord has given them into Israel’s control.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan crawled up on his hands and feet, with his armor bearer following him. The Philistines fell before Jonathan, and his armor bearer who was behind him also killed some.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the initial attack, Jonathan and his armor bearer struck down about twenty men in an area of about half an acre of land.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was terror in the camp, in the field, and among all the people. Even the garrison and the raiders were terrified. The earth shook, and there was even greater terror.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s sentries in Gibeah of Benjamin watched as the camp was in disarray, going this way and that.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told the people who were with him, “Do a roll call and see who has left us.” They did a roll call, and Jonathan and his armor bearer were not there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told Ahijah, “Bring the Ark of God here.” For at that time the Ark of God was with the Israelis.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Saul was still speaking to the priest, the commotion in the Philistine camp increased more and more, and Saul told the priest, “Remove your hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul and all the people who were with him assembled and went into battle. Now the swords of all the Philistines were against each other, and there was very great confusion.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Hebrews who had previously been with the Philistines, who had gone up with them from the surrounding areas to the camp, even they joined Israel and those who were with Saul and Jonathan.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Israelis who had been hiding in the hill country of Ephraim heard that the Philistines were fleeing, and even they pursued the Philistines in the battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the Lord delivered Israel, and the battle moved past Beth-aven.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel were hard pressed on that day, and Saul required the army to take an oath: “Cursed is the person who eats food before evening and before I’ve been avenged of my enemies.” So no one tasted food.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, all the soldiers entered the woods, and there was honey on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people came into the woods and there was flowing honey, but no one put his hand to his mouth to eat it because the people were afraid due to the oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jonathan had not heard that his father had required the army to swear an oath, so he stretched out the end of the staff that was in his hand and dipped it in the honeycomb. He brought it back to his mouth and his eyes brightened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of the people responded: “Your father strictly ordered the army to take an oath. That’s why he said, ‘Cursed is the person who eats food today,’ and so the army is exhausted.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said, “My father has troubled the land. See how my eyes have brightened because I tasted a little of this honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: How much better if the army had eaten freely today of their enemy’s spoil that they found, because the slaughter among the Philistines has not been great.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That day they struck down the Philistines from Michmash to Aijalon, and the army was very weary.
speaker: Narrator

text: The army grabbed the spoil, took sheep, oxen, and calves, and slaughtered them on the ground, and then the army ate them with the blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Someone reported this to Saul: “Right now the army is sinning against the Lord by eating meat with the blood.” He said, “You have acted treacherously. Roll a large stone to me today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said, “Disperse yourselves among the soldiers and say to them, ‘Let each man bring his ox and his sheep to me, and you are to slaughter them here and eat. But don’t sin against the Lord by eating meat with the blood.’” So every soldier brought his ox with him that night, and they slaughtered them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul built an altar to the Lord; it was the first altar that he built to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul said, “Let’s go down after the Philistines tonight and plunder them until dawn, and let’s not leave a single one of them alive.”
They said, “Do whatever seems good to you!”
But the priest said, “Let’s draw near to God here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul inquired of God, “Shall I go down after the Philistines? Will you give them into the hand of Israel?” But God did not answer him that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “All you army officers are to come here to find out what constitutes this sin today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, as the Lord who delivers Israel lives, even if the sin is with my son Jonathan, he will surely die!” Not a single one of the soldiers answered him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he told all Israel, “You will be on one side, and I and my son Jonathan will be on the other side.”
The people told Saul, “Do what seems good to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul told the Lord God of Israel, “Judge us properly.” Jonathan and Saul were selected, but the army was cleared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “Cast lots between me and my son Jonathan,” and Jonathan was selected.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul told Jonathan, “Tell me what you’ve done.”
So Jonathan spoke to him: “I did taste a little honey from the end of the staff that was in my hand. Here I am; I’m ready to die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “May God do this to me and even more, if you don’t surely die, Jonathan!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the army told Saul, “Shall Jonathan die, who brought about this great deliverance in Israel? As the Lord lives, not one hair of his head will fall to the ground, because today he did this with God’s help.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul stopped pursuing the Philistines, and the Philistines went back to their territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul became king over Israel, he fought against all his enemies on every side—against Moab, the Ammonites, Edom, the kings of Zobah, and the Philistines. Everywhere he turned he was victorious.
speaker: Narrator

text: He acted valiantly, defeated Amalek, and delivered Israel from those who had been plundering them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s sons included Jonathan, Ishvi, and Malchi-shua. Of his two daughters, the firstborn was named Merab, and the younger one was named Michal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s wife was Ahinoam, daughter of Ahimaaz, while the commander of his army was Saul’s uncle Ner’s son Abner.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s father Kish and Abner’s father Ner were sons of Abiel.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was intense fighting against the Philistines during Saul’s entire reign, and whenever Saul discovered a strong or valiant warrior, he would enlist him for service.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel told Saul, “The Lord sent me to anoint you king over his people, Israel. Now listen to the words of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies says: ‘I’ll punish Amalek for what he did to Israel, when he set himself against Israel in the way, as they were going up from Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, go and attack Amalek. Completely destroy all that they have. Don’t spare them, but put to death both man and woman, child and infant, both ox and sheep, camel and donkey.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul summoned the people and mustered them in Telaim, 200,000 foot soldiers and 10,000 men from Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul came to the city of Amalek and set an ambush in the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told the Kenites, “Withdraw from the Amalekites so that I don’t destroy you with them, for you showed kindness to all the Israelis when they departed from Egypt.” So the Kenites withdrew from the Amalekites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul attacked the Amalekites from Havilah to Shur, which is east of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He captured alive Agag king of Amalek, but he completely destroyed all the people, executing them with swords.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul and the people spared Agag and the best of the sheep and cattle—the fattened animals and lambs—along with all that was good. They were not willing to completely destroy them, but they did completely destroy everything that was worthless and inferior.
speaker: Narrator

text: This message from the Lord came to Samuel:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I regret that I made Saul king, because he has turned away from following me and has not carried out my commands.” Samuel was angry, and he cried out to the Lord all night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel got up early in the morning to meet Saul, but Samuel was told, “Saul went up to Carmel to set up a monument for himself. Then he turned around and traveled on to Gilgal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel approached Saul. “May the Lord bless you,” Saul said. “I’ve carried out the Lord’s command.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Then what is this bleating of sheep in my ears and the lowing of cattle that I hear?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul replied, “They brought them from the Amalekites. The people spared the best of the sheep and cattle to offer sacrifices to the Lord your God, and the rest they completely destroyed.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Be quiet!” Samuel said. “I’ll tell you what the Lord told me last night.”
Saul told him, “Speak.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel replied, “Is it not true that though you were small in your own eyes you became head of the tribes of Israel, and the Lord anointed you king over Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord sent you on a mission: ‘Go and completely destroy the sinners, the Amalekites, and fight against them until they’re destroyed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Why didn’t you obey the Lord, but grabbed the spoil and did evil in the Lord’s sight?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told Samuel, “I did obey the Lord. I went on the mission on which the Lord sent me, I brought Agag king of Amalek, and I completely destroyed the Amalekites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people took some of the spoil—sheep, cattle, and the best of what was to be completely destroyed—to sacrifice to the Lord your God at Gilgal.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel said,
“Does the Lord delight as much in burnt offerings and sacrifices
    as in obeying the Lord?
Surely, to obey is better than sacrifice,
    to pay attention is better than the fat of rams.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, rebellion is the sin of divination,
    and arrogance is iniquity and idolatry.
Because you have rejected this message from the Lord,
    he has rejected you from being king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’ve sinned,” Saul replied to Samuel. “I’ve broken the Lord’s command and your word, because I was afraid of the people and listened to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, please forgive my sin and return with me so I may worship the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel told Saul, “I won’t return with you because you have rejected the message from the Lord, and the Lord has rejected you from being king over Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Samuel turned to go Saul seized him by the corner of his robe, and it tore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel told him, “The Lord has torn the kingdom of Israel away from you today, and he has given it to your neighbor who is better than you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the Glory of Israel does not lie or change his mind, for he’s not a man that he should change his mind.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’ve sinned,” Saul said. “But please honor me now before the elders of my people and before Israel, and return with me so I may worship the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel returned, following Saul, and Saul worshipped the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Samuel said, “Bring Agag king of Amalek to me.”
Agag came to him in fetters, saying to himself, “Surely the bitterness of death is past.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Just as your sword has made women childless, so your mother will be childless among women.” Then Samuel cut Agag into pieces in the Lord’s presence in Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel went to Ramah, and Saul went to his house in Gibeah of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel did not see Saul again until the day of his death, but Samuel grieved over Saul, and the Lord regretted that he had made Saul king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Samuel, “How long will you grieve over Saul, since I’ve rejected him from being king over Israel? Fill your horn with oil and go. I’m sending you to Jesse from Bethlehem because I’ve chosen for myself one of his sons as king.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel said, “How can I go? Saul will hear about this and kill me!”
The Lord said, “Take a heifer with you and say, ‘I’ve come to offer a sacrifice to the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to invite Jesse to the sacrifice, and I’ll show you what you are to do. You are to anoint for me the one I tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel did what the Lord said and went to Bethlehem. The elders of the town came out to meet him trembling, and said, “May your coming be in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Peace, I’ve come to sacrifice to the Lord. Consecrate yourselves and come with me to the sacrifice.” Samuel consecrated Jesse and his sons and invited them to the sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arrived, Samuel saw Eliab, and said, “Surely he’s the Lord’s anointed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Samuel, “Don’t look at his appearance or his height, for I’ve rejected him. Truly, God does not see what man sees, for man looks at the outward appearance, but the Lord sees the heart.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesse summoned Abinadab and brought him before Samuel, and he said, “Neither has the Lord chosen this one.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesse brought Shammah, and he said, “Neither has the Lord chosen this one.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesse brought seven of his sons before Samuel, and Samuel told Jesse, “The Lord has not chosen these.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel told Jesse, “Are these all the young men?” He said, “There yet remains the youngest one, and right now he’s tending the sheep.” Samuel told Jesse, “Send someone to get him, for we won’t do anything else until he arrives here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he sent and brought him. He had a dark, healthy complexion, with beautiful eyes, and he was handsome. The Lord said, “Get up and anoint him, for this is the one.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel took the horn of oil and anointed David in the presence of his brothers, and the Spirit of the Lord came on David from that day forward. Then Samuel got up and went to Ramah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit of the Lord departed from Saul, and an evil spirit from the Lord troubled him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s servants told him, “Look, an evil spirit from God is troubling you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let our lord order his servants who attend you to look for a man who is skilled in playing the lyre. And then when an evil spirit from God comes on you, he will play and you will be better.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told his servants, “Find a man for me who can play well and bring him to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of the young men answered: “Look, I’ve seen a son of Jesse the Bethlehemite who is skilled in playing. The man is a valiant soldier, gifted in speech, and handsome. And the Lord is with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul sent messengers to Jesse and said, “Send me your son David, who is with the sheep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesse took a donkey loaded with bread, a container of wine, and one kid, and sent them to Saul along with his son David.
speaker: Narrator

text: David went to Saul and began to serve him. Saul loved him very much, and he became his armor bearer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul sent a messenger to Jesse to tell him, “Allow David to serve me, because I’m pleased with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever an evil spirit from God came to Saul, David would take the lyre and play it. Relief would come to Saul and he would be better, because the evil spirit would leave him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines assembled their army for battle. They were assembled at Socoh, which belongs to Judah, and they camped between Socoh and Azekah, in Ephes-dammim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul and the Israelis assembled and camped in the valley of Elah, where they set up their forces to meet the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines were standing on the hill on one side while the Israelis were standing on the hill on the other side, with the valley between them.
speaker: Narrator

text: A champion named Goliath from Gath came out from the Philistine camp. He was four cubits and a span tall,
speaker: Narrator

text: wore a bronze helmet on his head, and wore bronze scale armor that weighed about 5,000 shekels.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had bronze armor on his legs and carried a bronze javelin slung between his shoulders.
speaker: Narrator

text: The shaft of his spear was like a weaver’s beam and the iron point of his spear weighed 600 shekels. A man carrying his shield walked in front of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stood still and called out to the ranks of Israel, “Why should you move into position for battle? Am I not a Philistine and you Saul’s servants? Choose a man for yourselves to come down against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he’s able to fight me and strike me down, then we will become your servants; but if I prevail against him and strike him down, then you will become our servants and serve us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine said, “I defy the ranks of Israel today. Send me one man and let’s fight together.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul and all the Israelis heard these words of the Philistine, they were dismayed and very frightened.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was the son of that Ephrathite man named Jesse from Bethlehem in Judah. He had eight sons; at the time when Saul was king he was old, having lived to an advanced age.
speaker: Narrator

text: The three oldest sons of Jesse followed Saul into battle. The names of his three sons who went to the battle were his firstborn Eliab, Abinadab, his second son, and Shammah, the third.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was the youngest, while the three oldest had followed Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: And David would go back and forth from Saul to tend his father’s sheep in Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: For 40 days the Philistine would come forward, morning and evening, to take his position.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesse told his son David, “Take this ephah of roasted grain to your brothers, along with these ten loaves of bread, and quickly take them to your brothers in the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take these ten pieces of cheese to the commander of the unit, check on the well-being of your brothers, and bring something back from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul, your brothers, and all the men of Israel are in the valley of Elah fighting with the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David got up early in the morning, left the sheep with a keeper, took the supplies, and went as Jesse had directed him. He arrived at the encampment as the army was going out to the battle line, shouting the battle cry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel and the Philistines moved into position for battle, battle line facing battle line.
speaker: Narrator

text: David left the supplies he had with him in the care of the supply keeper and ran to the battle line. When he arrived there, he asked his brothers about their well-being.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he was speaking with them, the Philistine champion named Goliath from Gath came up from the Philistine battle lines and spoke his usual words, as David listened.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the Israelis saw the man, they fled from him and were very frightened.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Did all of you see this man coming up?” one Israeli asked. “He comes up to defy Israel, and the king will richly reward the man who kills him. He will give his daughter to him and will make his father’s house tax free in Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David asked the men who were standing by him, “What will be done for the man who kills this Philistine and takes away the reproach from Israel? Indeed, who is this uncircumcised Philistine that he should defy the armies of the living God?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people also told him the same thing, saying, “This is what will be done for the man who kills him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliab his oldest brother heard him talking to the men. Eliab was angry with David and said, “Why did you come down here? And who did you leave those few sheep with in the wilderness? I know your insolence and wicked intentions. You came down just to see the battle!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “What have I done now?” David asked. “It was just a question, wasn’t it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he turned from him toward another person and asked the same thing. The people replied to him the same way as the first one had.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the words that David had spoken were heard, they were reported to Saul, and he sent for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: David told Saul, “Let no one’s courage fail because of him; your servant will go fight this Philistine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told David, “You can’t go against this Philistine and fight him. You are only a young man, but he has been a warrior since his youth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David told Saul, “Your servant has been a shepherd for his father. When a lion or bear came and took a lamb from the flock,
speaker: Narrator

text: I would go out after it, strike it down, and rescue the lamb from its mouth. Then when it rose up against me, I would grab it by its fur, strike it down, and kill it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your servant has struck down both lions and bears, and this uncircumcised Philistine will be like one of them, since he defied the armies of the living God.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
David continued, “The Lord who delivered me from the power of the lion and the power of the bear will also deliver me from the power of this Philistine.”
Saul told David, “Go! And may the Lord be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul put his garments on David, set a bronze helmet on his head, and put armor on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: David strapped Saul’s sword over his garments and tried to walk, but he was not used to the armor. David told Saul, “I can’t walk in these because I’m not used to them,” and then took them off.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took his staff in his hand and chose for himself five smooth stones from the brook and put them in the pouch in his shepherd’s bag. He approached the Philistine with his sling in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: With a man carrying his shield in front of him, the Philistine kept coming closer to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistine looked and saw David, he had contempt for him, because he was only a young man. David had a dark, healthy complexion and was handsome.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine asked David, “Am I a dog that you come at me with sticks?” Then the Philistine cursed David by his own gods and
speaker: Narrator

text: told David, “Come to me! I’ll give your flesh to the birds of the sky and to the beasts of the field.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David told the Philistine, “You come at me with a sword, a spear, and a javelin, but I come to you in the name of the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of the armies of Israel whom you have defied.
speaker: Narrator

text: This very day the Lord will deliver you into my hand, and I’ll strike you down and remove your head from you. And this very day I’ll give the dead bodies of the Philistine army to the birds of the sky and to the animals of the earth, so that all the earth will know that there is a God in Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: and this whole congregation will know that the Lord does not deliver by sword or spear. Indeed, the battle is the Lord’s and he will give you into our hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistine got up and came closer to meet David, David quickly ran to the battle line to meet the Philistine.
speaker: Narrator

text: David reached his hand into the bag, took out a stone, slung it, and struck the Philistine in his forehead. The stone sunk into his forehead, and he fell on his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator
