text: David defeated the Philistine with a sling and a stone; he struck down the Philistine and killed him, and there was no sword in David’s hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: David ran and stood over the Philistine. He took the Philistine’s sword, pulled it from its sheath, killed him, and then he cut off his head with it. When the Philistines saw that their champion was dead, they fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel and Judah got up with a shout and pursued the Philistines as far as the entrance to the valley and to the gates of Ekron. Wounded Philistines fell along the way to Shaaraim as far as Gath and Ekron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelis returned from pursuing the Philistines and plundered their camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: David took the Philistine’s head and brought it to Jerusalem, but he put Goliath’s weapons in his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Saul saw David going out to meet the Philistine, he asked Abner, the commander of the army, “Whose son is this young man, Abner?”
Abner said, “As surely as you live, your majesty, I don’t know.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king replied, “Go find out whose son the young man is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David returned from striking down the Philistine, Abner took him and brought him to Saul with the Philistine’s head in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul told him, “Whose son are you, young man?”
David said, “The son of your servant Jesse of Bethlehem.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David finished speaking with Saul, Jonathan became a close friend to David, and Jonathan loved him as himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul took David that day and did not let him return to his father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan made a covenant with David because he loved him as he loved himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan took off the robe that he had on and gave it to David, along with his coat, his sword, his bow, and his belt.
speaker: Narrator

text: David went out and was successful everywhere Saul sent him, and Saul put him in charge of the troops. This pleased the entire army, as well as Saul’s officials.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David returned from defeating the Philistine, as they were entering the city, women from all the towns of Israel came out to meet King Saul, singing and dancing as they joyously played tambourines and lyres.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As the women sang and played, they said,
“Saul has struck down his thousands
    but David his ten thousands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul was very angry and he did not like what the women sang. He told himself, “They have attributed tens of thousands to David, but to me they have attributed thousands. What else can he have but the kingdom?”
speaker: Narrator

text: From then on Saul kept his eye on David.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, while David was playing the lyre as he had before, the evil spirit from the Lord attacked Saul, and he began to rave inside the house with a spear in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul hurled it, thinking, “I’ll pin David to the wall.” But David escaped from him twice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Saul was afraid of David because the Lord was with him and had departed from Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul removed David from his presence and made him an officer over a division of soldiers. So David led the troops in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was successful in all that he did, for the Lord was with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul saw that David was highly successful, he feared him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But all Israel and Judah loved David because he led them in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told David, “Here is my older daughter Merab. I’ll give her to you as a wife. Just be an excellent soldier for me and fight the Lord’s battles.” Now Saul told himself, “I won’t harm him myself. Instead, I’ll let the Philistines harm him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David told Saul, “Who am I and what is my life or my father’s family in Israel that I should be the king’s son-in-law?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the time came to give Saul’s daughter Merab to David, she was given as a wife to Adriel of Meholah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s daughter Michal loved David. Saul was informed of this and he liked the idea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told himself, “I’ll give her to him and she can be a snare to him and the Philistines will harm him.” So Saul told David, “For a second time you can be my son-in-law today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul commanded his officials, “Speak with David privately and say, ‘Look, the king delights in you, and all his officials love you. Now become the king’s son-in-law.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s officials delivered this message to David, and he asked, “Is becoming the king’s son-in-law an unimportant thing to you? I’m a poor and unimportant man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s officials reported to him: “This is what David said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “This is what you are to tell David, ‘The king desires no bride price except 100 Philistine foreskins to take vengeance on the king’s enemies.’” Now Saul thought he would cause David to die at the hand of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: When his officials delivered this message to David, David decided it would be a good thing to become the king’s son-in-law. Before the time was up,
speaker: Narrator

text: David got up, went out with his men, and struck down 200 Philistine men. David brought their foreskins and gave them all to the king so he could become the king’s son-in-law. So Saul gave him his daughter Michal as a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Saul continued to observe, he realized that the Lord was with David and that Saul’s daughter Michal loved him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul was even more afraid of David, and Saul was David’s enemy from that time on.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine commanders would go out to fight and whenever they did, David was more successful than any of Saul’s other leaders. His name was held in high esteem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told his son Jonathan and all his officials to kill David, but Saul’s son Jonathan was very fond of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jonathan told David, “My father Saul is trying to kill you. In the morning be careful and stay hidden in a secret place.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll go out and stand by my father in the field where you are. I’ll speak to my father about you. If I find out what he intends to do, I’ll tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan spoke to his father Saul favorably about David. “The king shouldn’t wrong his servant David because he has not wronged you and because what he has done has been very beneficial for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: He risked his life and struck down the Philistine, and the Lord brought about a spectacular deliverance for all Israel. You saw that and rejoiced, so why would you do wrong and shed innocent blood by killing David without cause?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul listened to Jonathan, and swore by the life of the Lord that David would not be killed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan summoned David and told him all this. Then Jonathan brought David to Saul, and David served him as before.
speaker: Narrator

text: The war continued and David went out to fight against the Philistines. He thoroughly defeated them, and they fled before David.
speaker: Narrator

text: The evil spirit from the Lord attacked Saul while he was sitting in his house with his spear in his hand and David was playing the lyre.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul tried to pin David to the wall with the spear, but he jumped away from Saul and the spear stuck in the wall. That night David escaped and fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul sent messengers to David’s house to watch him so they could kill him in the morning. David’s wife, Michal, told him, “If you don’t escape with your life tonight, tomorrow you’ll be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Michal let David down through the window, and he escaped and fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Michal took the household idol and laid it on the bed with a cover of goat hair placed at its head. Then she covered it with clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul sent the messengers to take David, Michal said, “He’s sick.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul sent messengers to check on David. He told them, “Bring him to me on the bed so I may kill him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The messengers went in, and there was the household idol in the bed with the cover of goat hair at its head!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Saul told Michal, “Why did you deceive me like this and let my enemy go so he could escape?”
Michal told Saul, “He told me, ‘Let me go or I’ll kill you!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: David escaped and fled. He came to Samuel at Ramah and told him all that Saul had done to him. Then he and Samuel went and stayed at Naioth.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was reported to Saul saying, “David is at Naioth in Ramah right now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul sent messengers to take David, and they saw a group of prophets caught up in prophetic ecstasy, with Samuel standing beside them leading them. Then the Spirit of God came on Saul’s messengers, and they also were caught up in prophetic ecstasy.
speaker: Narrator

text: They reported this to Saul, he sent other messengers, and they also were caught up in prophetic ecstasy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Saul himself went to Ramah, and he arrived at the large well that is in Secu. He asked, “Where are Samuel and David?”
Someone replied, “They’re at Naioth in Ramah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul went to Naioth in Ramah, and the Spirit of God came on him also. He continued in prophetic ecstasy until he came to Naioth in Ramah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also removed his clothes and was caught up in prophetic ecstasy right in front of Samuel! He fell down naked and remained there all that day and all night. That is why people say, “Is Saul also among the prophets?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David fled from Naioth in Ramah. He came to Jonathan and said, “What have I done? What is my crime, and how have I wronged your father so that he’s determined to kill me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan told him, “Far from it! You won’t die. Look, my father never does anything, great or small, without telling me; so why should my father hide this thing from me? It’s not like that!”
speaker: Narrator

text: David again took an oath: “Your father certainly knows that I’ve found favor with you, and so he told himself, ‘Jonathan must not know this so he won’t be upset.’ But as certainly as the Lord is alive and living, and as certainly as I’m alive and living, too, there is only a step between me and death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan told David, “Whatever you say, I’ll do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David told Jonathan, “Look, the New Moon is tomorrow, and I’m expected to sit down with the king to eat. Let me go so I can hide in the field until the evening of the day after tomorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your father actually notices that I’m not there, then you are to say, ‘David urgently requested that I allow him to run to his hometown of Bethlehem because the yearly sacrifice for the entire family was taking place there.’
speaker: Narrator

text: If he says, ‘Good,’ then your servant will be safe. But if he actually gets angry, you will know that his intentions are evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, show gracious kindness to your servant because you have entered into a sacred covenant with your servant. If there is iniquity in me, then kill me yourself—why should you bring me to your father?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Nonsense!” Jonathan replied. “If I actually knew that my father intended evil against you, wouldn’t I tell you about it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David told Jonathan, “Who will tell me if your father answers you harshly?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan told David, “Come, let’s go into the field.” So the two of them went into the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan told David, “The Lord God of Israel is my witness that I’ll carefully question my father by tomorrow or the next day. And if the response is favorable for David, will I not then send word to you and let you know?
speaker: Narrator

text: But if my father intends to harm you, may the Lord strike me dead if I don’t let you know and send you away so you may go safely. May the Lord be with you as he has been with my father.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I remain alive, don’t fail to show me the Lord’s gracious love so that I don’t die.
speaker: Narrator

text: And don’t stop showing your gracious love to my family forever, not even when the Lord eliminates each of David’s enemies from the surface of the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan made a covenant with the house of David: “May the Lord punish any violation of this covenant by the hand of David’s enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan made David vow again out of his love for him, because he loved him as himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan told him, “Tomorrow is the New Moon, and you will be missed because your seat is empty.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day go down quickly and come to the place where you hid earlier. Remain beside the rock at Ezel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll shoot three arrows to the side of the rock as though I were shooting at a target.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I’ll send a servant, saying, ‘Go, find the arrows.’ If I specifically say to the servant, ‘Look, the arrows are on this side of you, get them,’ then come out because it’s safe for you, and, as surely as the Lord lives, there is no danger.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if I say this to the young man: ‘Look, the arrows are beyond you,’ then go, for the Lord has sent you away.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the matter about which you and I spoke, remember that the Lord is a witness between us forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David hid in the field. When the New Moon arrived, the king sat down to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king sat down at his place as before, in the seat by the wall. Jonathan stood while Abner sat next to Saul, but David’s place was empty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul didn’t say anything that day because he told himself, “Something has happened; he’s unclean; surely he’s not clean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the next day, on the second day of the New Moon, David’s place was empty, and so Saul told his son Jonathan, “Why didn’t Jesse’s son come to the festival, either yesterday or today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan answered Saul, “David urgently requested that I let him go to Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, ‘Please let me go because our family has a sacrifice in the town, and my brother has ordered me to come. Now, if it’s acceptable to you, please let me get away so I can see my brothers.’ That’s the reason he didn’t come to the king’s table.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul flew into a rage and told Jonathan, “You son of a perverse and rebellious woman! Don’t I know that you have chosen Jesse’s son to your shame and to the shame of your mother who bore you?
speaker: Narrator

text: As long as Jesse’s son lives on the earth, neither you nor your kingdom will be established! Now send someone and bring David to me. He’s a dead man!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan asked his father Saul, “Why should he be killed? What did he do?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul threw the spear that was beside him to strike Jonathan down. So Jonathan realized that his father was determined to kill David.
speaker: Narrator

text: So on the second day of the New Moon Jonathan angrily got up from the table without eating because he was upset about David, and because his father had humiliated him.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning Jonathan, accompanied by a servant, went out to the field for the appointment with David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan told his servant, “Run, find the arrows that I’m shooting.” As the servant ran, Jonathan shot the arrow beyond him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The servant came to the place where Jonathan had shot it, and Jonathan called out to him, “The arrow is beyond you, isn’t it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan called out to the servant, “Hurry, be quick, don’t stand around.” Jonathan’s servant picked up the arrow and brought it to his master.
speaker: Narrator

text: The servant was not aware of anything. Only Jonathan and David understood what had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan gave his equipment to the servant who was with him and told him, “Go, take these things to the city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The servant went. Then David came out from the south side of the rock, fell on his face, and bowed down three times. The men kissed each other, and both of them cried, but David even more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jonathan told David, “Go in peace since both of us swore in the name of the Lord: ‘May the Lord be between me and you, and between my descendants and your descendants forever.’”
Then David got up and left, while Jonathan went to the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: David came to Nob to Ahimelech the priest, and Ahimelech was trembling as he came to meet David. Ahimelech told him, “Why are you alone, and no one with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David told Ahimelech the priest, “The king commanded me about a matter, saying to me, ‘Don’t let anyone know anything about the matter I’m sending you to do and about which I’ve commanded you. I’ve directed the young men to a certain place.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, what do you have available? Give me five loaves of bread or whatever you have.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest answered David: “There is no ordinary bread available; only consecrated bread, provided that the young men have kept themselves from women.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David answered the priest, saying to him, “Indeed, women were kept from us as is usual whenever I go out on a mission, and the equipment of the young men is consecrated even when it’s an ordinary journey, so how much more is their equipment consecrated today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priest gave him consecrated bread because no bread was there except the Bread of the Presence that had been removed from the Lord’s presence and replaced with hot bread on the day it was taken away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, Doeg the Edomite, one of Saul’s officials, was there that day, detained in the Lord’s presence. He was the chief of Saul’s shepherds.
speaker: Narrator

text: David told Ahimelech, “Is there no spear or sword available here? I took neither my sword nor my weapons with me, because the king’s mission is urgent.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The priest said, “The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you struck down in the Valley of Elah is wrapped up in a cloth behind the ephod. If you want it, take it because there is no other except it here.”
So David said, “There is none like it. Give it to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David got up that day and fled from Saul, and he went to King Achish of Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The officials of Achish told him, “Isn’t this David, king of the land? Isn’t this the one about whom they sang as they danced,
‘Saul has struck down his thousands,
    but David his ten thousands’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David took these words seriously, and he was very frightened of King Achish of Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David changed his behavior before them and acted like he was crazy in their presence. He scribbled on the doors of the gate, and let his saliva run down his beard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Achish told his officials, “Look, you see a person acting like a madman. Why’d you bring him to me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Am I lacking madmen that you bring me this one to act like a madman around me? Shall this one come into my house?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David left from there and escaped to the Cave of Adullam. His brothers and all his father’s family heard about this and went down to him there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who was in distress, everyone who was in debt, and everyone who was malcontent gathered around him, and he became their leader. There were about 400 men with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: David went from there to Mizpah of Moab, and he told the king of Moab, “Please let my father and mother come and stay with you until I know what God is going to do for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David left them with the king of Moab, and they stayed with him all the time David was in the stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet Gad told David, “Don’t remain in the stronghold. Go and enter the territory of Judah.” So David left and went into the forest of Hereth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul heard that David and the men who were with him had been found, he was sitting in Gibeah, under the tamarisk tree on the hill, with his spear in his hand. All his officials were standing around him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told his officials who were standing around him, “Listen, men of Benjamin! Will Jesse’s son also give fields and vineyards to all of you? Will he make all of you officers over thousands and officers over hundreds?
speaker: Narrator

text: But all of you have conspired against me, and no one tells me about my son’s covenant with Jesse’s son. None of you feels sorry for me and tells me that my son has stirred up my servant against me to lie in wait, as he’s doing this day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Doeg the Edomite, who was in charge of Saul’s servants answered: “I saw Jesse’s son coming to Nob to Ahitub’s son Ahimelech.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahimelech inquired of the Lord for him, gave him provisions, and gave him the sword of Goliath the Philistine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king sent for Ahitub’s son Ahimelech the priest and for all his father’s family who were priests at Nob. All of them came to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul said, “Listen, son of Ahitub!”
And he said, “Here I am, your majesty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul asked him, “Why have you conspired against me—you and Jesse’s son—by giving him food and a sword, and by inquiring of God for him, so he can rise up against me to lie in wait, as he’s doing today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahimelech answered the king, “Who among all your officials is as faithful as David? He is the king’s son-in-law, the captain of your bodyguard, and he’s honored in your household.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is today the first time I inquired of God for him? Absolutely not! The king shouldn’t accuse his servant, or any of my father’s family of anything, because your servant didn’t know anything at all about this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, “Ahimelech, you will surely die, you and all your father’s family!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king told the guards, who were standing beside him, “Turn and kill the priests of the Lord because they supported David, and because they knew he was fleeing, but didn’t inform me.” But the officials of the king did not want to lift their hands to attack the priests of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king told Doeg, “You turn and attack the priests.” Doeg the Edomite turned and attacked the priests. That day he killed eighty-five men who carry the linen ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: He attacked the priestly town of Nob with the sword. Men and women, children and infants, oxen, donkeys and sheep were put to the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: One man, Ahimelech’s son Abiathar, a grandson of Ahitub, escaped and fled to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abiathar told David that Saul had killed the priests of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: David told Abiathar, “I knew on that day when Doeg the Edomite was there that he would certainly tell Saul! I’m responsible for the deaths of your father’s whole family.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stay with me, and don’t be afraid because the one who seeks my life, seeks your life. Indeed, you will be safe with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Someone told David, “Look, the Philistines are fighting at Keilah and are plundering the threshing floors.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
David inquired of the Lord: “Shall I go and strike down these Philistines?”
The Lord told David, “Go strike down the Philistines and deliver Keilah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s men told him, “Look, we’re afraid here in Judah. How much then, if we go to Keilah against the Philistine army?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David inquired of the Lord again, and the Lord answered him: “Get up, go down to Keilah. I’ll give the Philistines into your control.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David and his men went to Keilah and fought the Philistines. He carried off their livestock and defeated them decisively, and so David delivered the inhabitants of Keilah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Ahimelech’s son Abiathar had fled to David in Keilah, the ephod had come down with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was reported to Saul that David had come to Keilah, and Saul said, “The Lord has delivered him into my hand because he has shut himself in by going into a town with double gates and bars.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul summoned for battle all his forces to go down to Keilah, to besiege David and his men.
speaker: Narrator

text: David knew that Saul was devising evil plans against him, and so he told Abiathar the priest, “Bring the ephod.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “Lord God of Israel. Your servant has definitely heard that Saul intends to come to Keilah to destroy the town because of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will the people of Keilah hand me over to him? Will Saul come down just as your servant has heard? Lord God of Israel, please inform your servant.”
The Lord said, “He will come down.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then David said, “Will the people of Keilah hand me over to Saul?”
The Lord said, “They’ll hand you over.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David and his men, about 600 strong, got up and left Keilah. They moved around wherever they could go. Saul was advised that David had escaped from Keilah, so he stopped the campaign.
speaker: Narrator

text: David stayed in the wilderness in the strongholds, and he lived in the hill country in the wilderness of Ziph. Saul sought him every day, but God did not let David slip into Saul’s control.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was afraid because Saul had come out to seek his life while David was in the wilderness of Ziph at Horesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s son Jonathan got up and went to David at Horesh, and he encouraged him to trust in God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan told him, “Don’t be afraid. My father Saul won’t find you, and you will be king over Israel. I’ll be your second-in-command. My father Saul also knows this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The two of them made a covenant in the Lord’s presence. David remained at Horesh while Jonathan went home.
speaker: Narrator

text: People from Ziph came up to Saul at Gibeah and informed him, “David is hiding with us in the strongholds in Horesh and on the hill of Hachilah south of Jeshimon, isn’t he?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, your majesty, whenever you want to come down, come down, and our part will be to hand him over to the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “May you be blessed by the Lord, because you have been gracious to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and again make sure, find out and investigate where he is and who has seen him there, for people tell me that he’s very clever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Investigate and find out all the hiding places there where he hides, and return to me with reliable information. Then I’ll go down with you, and if he’s in the land, I’ll search him out among all the thousands of Judah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people from Ziph got up and left Saul, while David and his men were in the wilderness of Maon in the Arabah south of Jeshimon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul and his men went to search for David, some people told David, and he went down to the Rock of Escape and remained in the wilderness of Maon. Saul heard this and he pursued David into the wilderness of Maon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul went on one side of the mountain while David and his men went on the other side of the mountain. David was hurrying to get away from Saul while Saul and his men were closing in on David and his men to capture them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a messenger came to Saul with this news: “Come quickly, because the Philistines have made a raid on the land!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul turned around from pursuing David and went to meet the Philistines. Therefore, they call that place the Rock of Escape.
speaker: Narrator

text: David went up from there and stayed in the strongholds of En-gedi.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul returned from pursuing the Philistines, he was told, “Look, David is in the wilderness of En-gedi.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul took 3,000 of his best troops from all over Israel, and he went to look for David and his men in the direction of the Rocks of the Wild Goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came to the sheepfolds beside the road. There was a cave there, and Saul went in to relieve himself. Now David and his men were sitting in the inner recesses of the cave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David’s men told him, “Look, today is the day about which the Lord spoke to you when he said, ‘I’ll give your enemy into your hand.’ Do to him whatever you want!”
David rose and stealthily cut off the corner of Saul’s robe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterwards, David’s conscience bothered him because he had cut off the corner of Saul’s robe.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told his men, “God forbid that I should do this thing to your majesty, the Lord’s anointed, by stretching out my hand against him, since he’s the Lord’s anointed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David restrained his men with his words and did not allow them to rebel against Saul. Saul got up from the cave and started off.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David got up, went out of the cave, and called out to Saul: “Your majesty!” Saul looked behind him, and David bowed down with his face to the ground and prostrated himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David told Saul, “Why do you listen to the words of those who say, ‘Look, David is trying to harm you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, this very day you saw with your own eyes that the Lord gave you into my control in the cave, and one of my men told me to kill you, but I had pity on you and responded, ‘I won’t lift my hand against his majesty because he’s the Lord’s anointed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, my father, look! The corner of your robe is in my hand. Indeed, by my cutting off the corner of your robe and not killing you, you may know and understand that I have no evil intent or transgression—I haven’t wronged you, even though you are hunting me to take my life.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord judge between me and you, and may he take vengeance on you for me, but I won’t be attacking you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just like the ancient proverb says, ‘From wicked people comes wickedness,’ but I’m not against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: After whom is the king of Israel going out? Whom are you pursuing? A dead dog or a single flea?
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord act as judge, and may he decide between me and you. May he see, may he plead my case, and may he vindicate me in this dispute against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David had finished saying these things to Saul, Saul asked, “Is this your voice, my son David?” Then Saul cried loudly
speaker: Narrator

text: to David, “You are more righteous than I am, because you have treated me well even though I’ve treated you poorly.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have explained how you treated me well, in that the Lord delivered me into your hand but you didn’t kill me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For who would find his enemy and then send him away safely? May the Lord repay you for what you have done for me today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I know for certain that you will be king, and that the kingdom will be established under your authority.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now swear to me by the Lord that you will never eliminate my descendants after me, and that you won’t erase my name from my father’s family.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David made this vow to Saul, and then Saul went home, while David and his men went up to the stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel died and all Israel assembled to mourn for him. They buried him at his home in Ramah.
David got up and went down to the Wilderness of Paran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a man in Maon whose business was in Carmel of Judah, and the man was very rich. He had 3,000 sheep and 1,000 goats, and he was shearing his sheep in Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man’s name was Nabal and his wife’s name was Abigail. The woman was intelligent and beautiful, while the man was harsh and wicked in his dealings. He was a descendant of Caleb.
speaker: Narrator

text: While David was in the wilderness, he heard that Nabal was shearing his sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: David sent ten young men, saying to the young men, “Go up to Carmel, find Nabal, and greet him in my name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then say, ‘May you live long. Peace to you, peace to your family, and peace to all that you have.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, I’ve heard that the sheep shearers are with you. Now, your shepherds have been with us. We didn’t harm them, and they didn’t miss anything all the time they were in Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ask your young men and they’ll tell you. Therefore let my young men find favor with you since we came on a special day. Please give whatever you have available to your servants and to your son David.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s young men came to Nabal and told him all this in David’s name, and then they waited.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nabal answered David’s servants: “Who is David? Who is this son of Jesse? There are many servants today who are breaking away from their masters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Should I take my food, my water, and my meat that I’ve slaughtered for my shearers and give it to men who came from who knows where?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s men turned and went on their way. They came back and told David everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: David told his men, “Put on your swords.” They put on their swords, and David put on his sword. Then about 400 men followed David, while 200 stayed with the supplies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, one of the young men told Nabal’s wife Abigail: “Look, David sent messengers from the wilderness to greet our lord, but he screamed insults at them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men were very good to us. They didn’t harm us, and we didn’t miss anything all the time we moved around with them when we were in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were a wall around us both day and night, all the time we were with them taking care of the sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, be aware of this and consider what you should do. Calamity is being planned against our master and against his entire household. He’s such a worthless person that no one can talk to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abigail quickly took 200 loaves of bread, two skins of wine, five butchered sheep, five measures of roasted grain, 100 bunches of raisins, and 200 fig cakes and loaded them on donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: She told her young men, “Go ahead of me, I’ll be coming right behind you.” But she said nothing to her husband Nabal.
speaker: Narrator

text: She was riding on the donkey and as she went down a protected part of the mountain, David was there with his men, coming down to meet her, and she went toward them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David had said, “Surely it was for nothing that I protected everything that belonged to this man in the wilderness, and nothing was missing of all that belonged to him. But he has repaid me with evil for good!
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord do this to the enemies of David—and more also—if by the morning I’ve left alive a single male of all those who belong to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abigail saw David, she quickly got down from the donkey and fell on her face before David, prostrating herself on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: She fell at his feet and pleaded, “Your majesty, let the guilt be on me alone, and please let your servant speak to you. Listen to the words of your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please, your majesty, don’t pay attention to this worthless man Nabal, for he’s just like his name. Nabal is his name and folly is his constant companion. But I, your servant, didn’t see your majesty’s young men whom you sent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, your majesty, as the Lord lives and as you live, the Lord has kept you from shedding blood and from delivering yourself by your own actions. Now, may your enemies and those seeking to do evil to your majesty be like Nabal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now let this present that your servant has brought to your majesty be given to the young men who follow your majesty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please forgive the offense of your servant. For the Lord will certainly make a strong dynasty for your majesty, for your majesty is fighting the Lord’s battles. May evil not be found in you for all of your life.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone should arise to pursue you and seek your life, may the life of your majesty be bound up with the Lord your God in a bundle of the living, and may he sling out the lives of your enemies from the pocket of a sling.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord does for your majesty all the good that he promised concerning you and appoints you Commander-in-Chief over Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: this shouldn’t be an obstacle or stumbling block for your majesty’s conscience, that he poured out blood without cause or that your majesty delivered himself. When the Lord does good things for your majesty, remember your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David told Abigail, “Blessed be the Lord God of Israel, who sent you to meet me today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Blessed be your good judgment, and blessed be you, who today stopped me from shedding blood and delivering myself by my own actions.
speaker: Narrator

text: For as surely as the Lord God of Israel lives, the one who restrained me from harming you—indeed, had you not quickly come to meet me, by dawn there wouldn’t be a single male left to Nabal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David took from her what she had brought him and told her, “Go up to your house in peace. Look, I’ve heard your request and will grant it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abigail returned to Nabal, and he was there in his house holding a festival like the festival of a king. Nabal’s heart was glad, and he was very drunk, so she didn’t tell him anything at all until morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Nabal became sober the next morning, his wife told him all that had happened. Nabal’s heart failed and he became paralyzed.
speaker: Narrator

text: About ten days later the Lord struck Nabal, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When David heard that Nabal had died, he said, “Blessed be the Lord who has judged the dispute over my insult at the hand of Nabal, and has held back his servant from evil. The Lord has repaid Nabal’s wickedness.”
Then David sent word to Abigail that he would take her as his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s servants went to Abigail at Carmel and told her, “David sent us to you to take you to him as his wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She got up, prostrated herself face down on the ground, and replied, “Your servant would be a slave to wash the feet of your majesty’s servants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abigail quickly got up and got on a donkey, with five young women walking behind her. She followed David’s messengers, and she became his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also married Ahinoam of Jezreel, and both of them became his wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Saul had given his daughter Michal, David’s wife, to Laish’s son Palti from Gallim.
speaker: Narrator

text: People from Ziph came to Saul in Gibeah and informed him, “David is hiding on the hill of Hachilah which is across from Jeshimon, isn’t he?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul rose and went down with 3,000 select men of Israel to the Wilderness of Ziph, to look for David in the Wilderness of Ziph.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul camped by the road on the hill of Hachilah, across from Jeshimon, while David was staying in the wilderness. When he realized that Saul had come after him in the wilderness,
speaker: Narrator

text: David sent out spies and found out for certain that Saul had arrived.
speaker: Narrator

text: David rose and went to the place where Saul was camped. David saw the place where Saul and Abner, his Commander-in-Chief, lay down. Saul was lying down within the encampment, and the army was camped all around him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David said to Ahimelech the Hittite, and to Joab’s brother Abishai, Zeruiah’s son, “Who will go down with me to Saul in the camp?”
Abishai said, “I’ll go down with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David and Abishai went to the army at night, and Saul was lying there asleep in the encampment. His spear was stuck in the ground at his head, and Abner and the army were lying all around him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abishai told David, “Today God has delivered your enemy into your hand. Let me run the spear through him into the ground with a single blow. I won’t need to strike him twice!”
speaker: Narrator

text: David told Abishai, “Don’t destroy him. Who can raise his hand to strike the Lord’s anointed and remain innocent?
speaker: Narrator

text: As the Lord lives, the Lord will strike him down, or his time will come to die, or he will go into battle and perish.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord forbid that I should raise my hand against the Lord’s anointed. Now take the spear that is at his head and the jug of water, and let’s go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David took the spear and the jug of water at Saul’s head, and they left. No one saw, and no one knew, because no one was awake. They were all asleep, because a deep sleep from the Lord had fallen over them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David crossed over to the other side and stood on top of the hill some distance away with a large distance between them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David called out to the army and to Ner’s son Abner, “Abner, won’t you answer me?”
Abner answered: “Who are you who calls out to the king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David told Abner, “Are you not a man, and who is like you in Israel? Why didn’t you guard your lord, the king? Indeed, a soldier came to destroy the king, your lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This thing that you did is not good. As the Lord lives, you deserve to die, you who didn’t guard your lord, the Lord’s anointed. Where is the king’s spear and where is the jug of water that was at his head?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul recognized David’s voice and said, “Is this your voice, my son David?”
David replied, “It is my voice, your majesty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “Why is your majesty pursuing his servant? For what have I done, and what evil do I bear toward you?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now let your majesty listen to the words of his servant. If the Lord incited you against me, then may he accept an offering. But if it is people, may they be cursed in the Lord’s presence, because they have driven me out today from sharing in the inheritance of the Lord by saying, ‘Go serve other gods.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, don’t let my blood fall to the ground away from the Lord’s presence. Indeed, the king of Israel has come out to seek a single flea, like someone hunts a partridge in the mountains.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said, “I’ve wronged you. Return, my son David, for I won’t harm you again because my life was precious to you today. Look, I’ve acted foolishly and have made a very great mistake.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David replied, “Here’s the king’s spear. Have one of the young men come over and get it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord repays a person for his righteousness and his faithfulness. The Lord gave you into my control today, but I refused to raise my hand against the Lord’s anointed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, just as your life was valuable in my eyes today, so may my life be valuable in the Lord’s eyes, and may he deliver me from all trouble.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told David, “Blessed are you, my son David. In whatever you do you will surely succeed.” So David went on his way, and Saul returned to his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: David told himself, “One of these days I’ll perish by Saul’s hand. There is nothing better for me to do than to escape to Philistine territory. Saul will give up searching for me anymore within the borders of Israel, so I’ll escape from him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David got up, and he and the 600 men who were with him went to Maoch’s son Achish, the king of Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: David stayed with Achish in Gath along with his men, each of whom was with his household. David had his two wives, Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail, who had been the wife of Nabal of Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul was told that David had fled to Gath, and he did not continue to search for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: David told Achish, “If it pleases you, give me a place in one of the outlying towns, so I may live there. Why should your servant live with you in the royal city?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So that day Achish gave him Ziklag, and therefore, Ziklag has belonged to the kings of Judah until the present time.
speaker: Narrator

text: David lived in Philistine territory for a year and four months.
speaker: Narrator

text: David and his men went up and raided the descendants of Geshur, the descendants of Girzi, and the Amalekites, for they had been living in the land since ancient times, from the entrance of Shur all the way to the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: David struck the land and did not leave a man or woman alive. He took sheep, cattle, donkeys, camels, and clothing, and then came back and went to Achish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Achish said, “Where did you raid today?”
David answered, “Against the Negev of Judah, against the Negev of the Jerahmeelites, and against the Negev of the Kenites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David did not leave a man or woman alive to bring to Gath. He told himself, “Otherwise, they’ll say, ‘This is what David is doing, and this has been his practice all the time he has lived in Philistine territory.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Achish believed David, telling himself, “He has certainly made himself repulsive to his people in Israel. He will be my servant forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the Philistines assembled their army for war to fight against Israel. Achish told David, “You know, of course, that you and your men will go out with me into the battle.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
David told Achish, “Very well, you will now see what your servant will do.”
Achish told David, “Very well, I’ll appoint you as my permanent bodyguard.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Samuel had died, and all Israel had mourned for him and buried him in his own town of Ramah. Saul had expelled the mediums and spiritists from the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines assembled, moved out, and camped at Shunem, while Saul assembled all Israel and camped at Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul saw the Philistine camp, he was afraid, and his heart trembled greatly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul inquired of the Lord, but the Lord did not answer him, either through dreams or Urim or through prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul told his servants, “Find me a woman who is a medium so I can go to her and make my inquiry through her.”
His servants told him, “Look, there’s a woman at Endor who is a medium.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul disguised himself, putting on different clothes. He went along with two men to the woman at night. He said, “Consult a familiar spirit for me and bring up for me the one whom I tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman told him, “Look, you know what Saul has done. He has removed mediums and spiritists from the land, so why are you trying to entrap me, so as to cause my death?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul swore to her by the Lord: “As surely as the Lord lives, no punishment will come on you for this thing.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The woman said, “Whom shall I bring up for you?”
Saul said, “Bring up Samuel for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the woman saw Samuel, she cried out loudly. The woman told Saul, “Why have you deceived me? You are Saul!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king told her, “Don’t be afraid; but what do you see?”
The woman told Saul, “I see a divine being coming up out of the ground.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul told her, “What does he look like?”
She said, “An old man is coming up, and he’s wrapped in a robe.” Saul knew that it was Samuel, and he bowed low to the ground and prostrated himself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel told Saul, “Why did you disturb me by bringing me up?”
Saul said, “I’m in great distress. The Philistines are waging war against me. God has departed from me and won’t answer me anymore, either by messages written by the hand of the prophets or by dreams. So I’ve summoned you to tell me what I should do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Why do you ask me, since the Lord has departed from you and become your enemy?
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has done to you exactly as he spoke through me. The Lord has torn the kingdom away from you and has given it to your colleague David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you didn’t obey the Lord and didn’t display his fierce anger against Amalek, therefore, the Lord will do this thing to you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord is giving both you, and Israel with you, into Philistine control. Tomorrow, the Lord will give you, your sons with you, and also the army of Israel into the control of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul immediately fell down full-length on the ground. He was terrified because of Samuel’s words, and he had no strength because he had not eaten food all day and all night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the woman came to Saul and saw that he was very disturbed. She told him, “Look, your servant obeyed you. I put my life into your hands, and I listened to your words that you spoke to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, please listen to your servant. I’ll put a piece of bread before you so you can eat and have strength to go on your way.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul refused, saying, “I won’t eat!”
Both his servants and the woman urged him, and so he listened to them. He got up off the ground and sat on the bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman had a fattened calf in the house, and she quickly slaughtered it. She took flour, kneaded it, and baked unleavened bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: She brought it to Saul and to his servants, and they ate. Then they got up and went out that night.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines gathered all their troops at Aphek, while Israel was camped at the spring in Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine leaders were passing in review among the military units, and David and his men were among them in the rear with Achish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Philistine leaders said, “What are these Hebrews doing here?”
Achish asked the Philistine leaders, “Isn’t this David, the servant of King Saul of Israel, who has been with me these days, or rather these years? I’ve found no fault in him from the day he deserted until now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Philistine leaders were angry with him, so they pleaded with him, “Send the man back! Let him return to the place you assigned him. He mustn’t go into battle with us. Otherwise, he may become our adversary in the battle! How could there be a better way for this fellow to reconcile himself with his lord? Wouldn’t it be with the heads of these men?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Isn’t this the same David about whom the maidens sang when they were dancing,
‘Saul has struck down his thousands,
    but David his ten thousands’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Achish summoned David and told him, “As surely as the Lord lives, you are trustworthy, and it seems good to me for you to campaign with me as part of the army. Indeed, I’ve not found any evil in you from the time you came to me until now. But the leaders don’t approve of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now return and go in peace, so you do nothing to displease the Philistine leaders.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David told Achish, “What have I done, and what have you found in your servant from the time I came before you until this very moment, that I shouldn’t go out and fight the enemies of your majesty?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Achish answered David, “I know that I’m pleased with you. You’re like an angel of God. But the Philistine leaders have said, ‘He mustn’t go into battle with us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, get up early in the morning along with your lord’s servants who came with you. Get up early in the morning, and go as soon as you have light.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and his men got up early in the morning to return to Philistine territory, while the Philistines went up to Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David and his men came to Ziklag on the third day, the Amalekites had raided the Negev and Ziklag. They had attacked Ziklag and set it on fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took the women in it captive, from young to old. They did not kill anyone. Instead, they carried them off and went on their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: David and his men came to the town, and it had been burned down. Their wives, their sons, and their daughters had been taken captive.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David and the people who were with him lifted their voices and cried until they had no more strength left to cry.
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s two wives, Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail, Nabal’s former wife, had been captured.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was in great danger because all the people were bitter because of their sons and daughters, and they were talking about stoning him. But David found strength in the Lord his God.
speaker: Narrator

text: David told Ahimelech’s son Abiathar the priest, “Bring me the ephod.” So Abiathar brought the ephod to David.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David inquired of the Lord: “Shall I pursue this raiding party? Will I overtake them?”
The Lord told David, “Pursue them! You will definitely overtake them and rescue the captives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and 600 men who were with him set out. They came to the Wadi Besor where those who were left behind stayed.
speaker: Narrator

text: David and 400 men continued the pursuit, while the 200 men who were too exhausted to cross over the Wadi Besor remained there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They found an Egyptian man in the field, and they took him to David. They gave him food to eat and provided water for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They gave him part of a fig cake and two bunches of raisins. After he had eaten, he revived, since he had neither eaten food nor had he drunk water for three days and three nights.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David told him, “To whom do you belong and where are you from?”
The Egyptian replied, “I’m a young Egyptian man, the slave of an Amalekite man. My master abandoned me, because I got sick three days ago.
speaker: Narrator

text: We raided the Negev of the Cherethites, the territory that belongs to Judah, and the Negev of Caleb, and we set Ziklag on fire.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
David asked him, “Will you take me to this raiding party?”
He said, “Swear to me by God that you won’t kill me or turn me over to my master, and I’ll take you to the raiding party.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptian led him to the camp, and there the Amalekites were spread out over the whole area, eating, drinking, and celebrating with the great amount of spoil they had taken from the territory belonging to the Philistines and to Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: David struck them down from twilight until the evening of the next day, and not one of them escaped except for 400 young men who mounted camels and fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: David rescued everyone whom the Amalekites had captured, including his two wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nothing of theirs was missing, whether small or large, sons or daughters, spoil, or anything that they had taken for themselves—David brought back everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: David took all the rest of the sheep and cattle, driving them ahead of their rescued livestock. People said about all this, “This is David’s spoil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David came to the 200 men who were too exhausted to follow him and who had been left at the Wadi Besor. They came out to meet David and the people who were with him. As David approached the people, he asked them how they were doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: At this point, all the wicked and worthless men of the group who had gone with David answered, “Because they didn’t go with us, we won’t give them any of the spoil that we recovered, except that each person may take his wife and his children and go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “No, you won’t do this, my brothers, with what the Lord has given us. He guarded us and gave the raiding party that came against us into our hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who will listen to you in this matter? Indeed, the share of those who went down into battle and the share of those who stayed with the supplies will be the same. They’ll share alike.”
speaker: Narrator

text: From that day forward he made it a statute and an ordinance for Israel, and it remains to this present day.
speaker: Narrator

text: David came to Ziklag, and he sent some of the spoil to the elders of Judah, and to his friends, telling them, “Look, this is a gift for you from the spoil of the enemies of the Lord
speaker: Narrator

text: in Bethel, Ramoth-negev, Jattir,
speaker: Narrator

text: Aroer, Siphmoth, Eshtemoa,
speaker: Narrator

text: Rachal, in the Jerahmeelite towns, in the Kenite towns,
speaker: Narrator

text: in Hormah, Bor-ashan, Athach,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hebron, and for all those places where David and his men had frequented.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines fought against Israel, and the army of Israel fled before the Philistines. They fell slain on Mount Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines pursued Saul and his sons. The Philistines struck down Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchi-shua, Saul’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: The heaviest fighting was directed toward Saul, and when the bowmen who were shooting located Saul, he was severely wounded by them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told his armor bearer, “Draw your sword and run me through with it, or these uncircumcised people will come and run me through and make sport of me.” But his armor bearer did not want to do it because he was very frightened, so Saul took the sword and fell on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When his armor bearer saw that Saul was dead, he also fell on his sword and died with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, Saul, his three sons, his armor bearer, and all his men died together that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of Israel who were across the valley and who were across the Jordan saw that the army of Israel had fled, and that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned the cities and fled, and the Philistines came and occupied them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, the Philistines came to strip the dead, and they found Saul and his three sons fallen on Mount Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cut off his head and stripped him of his weapons. They sent people throughout the territory of the Philistines to report the good news in the temples of their idols and to the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: They put Saul’s weapons in the temple of Asherah and fastened his corpse to the wall of Beth-shan.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the residents of Jabesh-gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,
speaker: Narrator

text: every valiant soldier got up, traveled all night, and removed Saul’s body and the bodies of his sons from the wall of Beth-shan. Then they went to Jabesh and cremated the bodies there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took their bones, buried them under the tamarisk tree in Jabesh, and fasted for seven days.
speaker: Narrator
